Bassman

sglaine put together a very good subject. I would like to expand on it mor by asking this: What is the best bass guitars in your opinion? I play an Ibanez SR-400 Soundgear bass which I absolutely love. Primarily for its feel and sound. I used to own a '78 Fender Precision for about 19 years which I also liked (wish I never parted with it emoticon_cool )
jitobear

I have only been playing for about three years and only get to it when I can (which is not as much as I would like being a single mum and all)...I played several peices of XXXX - but now I have an Ibanez Roadster. She is heavy as hell - but sounds oh so pretty. I ounce picked up a Fender Prodigy and fell in love because it was small and I have small girl hands. 
 
 I am not as well versed on what basses are THE BEST as I probably should be, but I have heard nothing but fond words from owners of MusicMan basses.
billsco

Fender Jazzman was king for many years. I won't even pretend to weigh in on all the new makes and models out there today. 
 
 A bass note isn't all that critical tone wise. You can get a solid bottom or a trebly twang with any model. I would say find the scale that fits your hands like jitobear alludes to. That would be the most important.
Bassman

Fender Jazzman was king for many years. I won't even pretend to weigh in on all the new makes and models out there today. 
 
 A bass note isn't all that critical tone wise. You can get a solid bottom or a trebly twang with any model. I would say find the scale that fits your hands like jitobear alludes to. That would be the most important.

 A correction, billsco, that's a Fender Jazz Bass . You are right, also about comfort. I have tried many good basses that I found difficult to play. :)
Bassman

I have only been playing for about three years and only get to it when I can (which is not as much as I would like being a single mum and all)...I played several peices of XXXX - but now I have an Ibanez Roadster. She is heavy as hell - but sounds oh so pretty. I ounce picked up a Fender Prodigy and fell in love because it was small and I have small girl hands. 
 
 I am not as well versed on what basses are THE BEST as I probably should be, but I have heard nothing but fond words from owners of MusicMan basses.

 I believe the Soundgear line would serve you purposes well. Not only that I play one myself, but,based on experience and my 23+ years of bass, I think it may serve you well. :) :)
Captain America banned

I am long time fan of the Fender Jazz as well as the Precision. But I absolutely LOVE my new Precision (American) with the S-1 switch. You get the best of both worlds. Click, it's a Jazz, click it's back to a Precision. Reasonably priced at about a grand.
 
 ALSO, there is a bass out there that doesn't get it's props. That is the Peavey Cirrus. I wouldn't give twp cents for most Peavey guitars (but their amps kick butt.) But the Cirrus rocks. Get ready to spend some money though. The Cirrus don't come cheap. The top line G&L's kick butt too. I also like the Lakland.
